repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fixes #20907.

I'm not sure if this is the ideal fix. Here are my thoughts:

The documentation for `:h vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf` states:

> Sets the current buffer in a window, **without side effects**

If I understand this correctly, "without side effects" means that it doesn't cause the cursor to enter the buffer and therefore shouldn't trigger autocommands.

However, the underlying implementation, [`win_set_buf`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f3ee2440c781e978777d9369a96d1ae32e12eb8f/src/nvim/window.c?plain=1#L751), does trigger autocommands.
And this appears to be intentional, with functions like `nvim_open_win` relying on this behaviour:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f3ee2440c781e978777d9369a96d1ae32e12eb8f/src/nvim/api/win_config.c?plain=1#L323-L330

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f3ee2440c781e978777d9369a96d1ae32e12eb8f/test/functional/api/window_spec.lua?plain=1#L2094-L2102

So my proposed hotfix is to wrap the `win_set_buf()` call in `block_autocmds()` and `unblock_autocmds()` calls in `nvim_win_set_buf`.

I don't think this is an ideal solution. Probably, `win_set_buf` shouldn't be triggering autocmd events, but changing that seems too risky; see also:

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14531

comment_regular_data.body:
So, the history of this is a bit confusing...

`nvim_win_set_buf` started off using `switch_win`, which blocked all autocommands from switching the window _and_ the buffer, but the original doc claimed it only quashed side-effects from [switching the window](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/9100/changes#diff-ebab59fd6849aad5d80f906ff7c0d301f377bd9e327a0f0e097978ff96fba854R37)... 

When it was merged it was changed to the [doc we have today](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/b1aaa0a881ef36676ddd71e7308ae7461c62896d#diff-ebab59fd6849aad5d80f906ff7c0d301f377bd9e327a0f0e097978ff96fba854R37), which was more accurate for the time, but now I'm unsure what #9100's original intent was.

Then #13664 changed it to only quash autocommands from switching the window (what we have today), but the doc wasn't updated. However, [its commit](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/1def3d1542d6a65f057e743faea39a760b50db87) describes a rather confusing interpretation of "without side-effects" to mean firing _more_ autocommands...

Naturally, that broke many plugins at the time due to the extra side-effects, namely concerning `nvim_open_win` (which called `nvim_win_set_buf`), so #14531 temporarily reverted it for a few hours until `noautocmd` was added to `nvim_open_win` as a workaround in #14659.

Personally, I think the behaviour we have today makes the most sense and that the doc should be clearer about the minimized side-effects applying to switching the window (which aims to be mostly invisible), _not_ the buffer; the current behaviour is analogous to `nvim_win_call/win_execute + nvim_set_current_buf/:buffer`, which I think is fine.

Ideally once `vim._with` is ready for public use it'll make it easier to block autocommands from Lua without needing to touch `:noautocmd` or `&eventignore`.

@seandewar thanks for the insight.

> Personally, I think the behaviour we have today makes the most sense and that the doc should be clearer about the minimized side-effects applying to switching the window (which aims to be mostly invisible), not the buffer; the current behaviour is analogous to `nvim_win_call/win_execute + nvim_set_current_buf/:buffer`, which I think is fine.

I'm not sure I understand this. Why do you think the current behaviour makes the most sense?
As a user, observing the behaviour of:

```lua
:lua new_win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(0, false, { split = 'left', win = 0, })
:lua new_buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)
:lua vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(new_win, new_buf)
```

the cursor doesn't appear to jump to `new_win` (or `new_buf`). In order for me to be able to reason about autocommands being triggered, I need to know about the internal implementation detail of the temporary window switch and the `do_buffer(DOBUF_GOTO, ...)` that temporarily "visits" the buffer.

It's the same for `nvim_open_win`. The fact that there's a temporary "visit" of the buffer is hidden from the user.

Edit: Here's another example of why this may be unintuitive from a plugin developer's or user's point of view:

```lua
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("BufEnter", { callback = function(ev) 
  print("BufEnter: " .. ev.buf) 
end, })
new_win = vim.api.nvim_open_win(0, false, { split = 'left', win = 0, })
new_buf = vim.api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)
vim.api.nvim_win_set_buf(new_win, new_buf)
-- prints "BufEnter: <new_buf>"
vim.api.nvim_set_current_win(new_win)
-- prints "BufEnter: <new_buf>" again
```

Main concern (also noted [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14531#issuecomment-838119219)) is that this PR is regressive for buffers that haven't yet been visited in a window before calling `nvim_win_set_buf`. For example, like this PR, the following skips filetype detection, syntax highlighting, etc.:
```vim
noautocmd call nvim_win_set_buf(0, bufadd(expand('$VIMRUNTIME/example_init.lua')))
```

That said, I understand the order of events can be janky, especially with missing `BufLeave`s, though it's not totally unique to `nvim_win_set_buf` (e.g: changing buffers in `win_execute`/`nvim_win_call`, or in `++nested` autocommands fired by code using `aucmd_prepbuf`, and who knows how many other places...)

Could consider blocking `Enter`/`Leave` events (excluding `BufWin*`) only for non-current windows (like `nvim_open_win`), but in some cases even `BufEnter` autocommands are used to set up buffers in scripts... :pensive:

A compromise to fix the mismatched events without blocking them _could_ even be to just make the window switching visible? (or only block the `Win*` events...)

Oof, that makes sense :sweat_smile:
I guess another compromise could be to add a `noautocmd` option to `nvim_win_set_buf`, too?

The "without side-effects" doc is definitely misleading. I would suggest to remove the "side-effects" wording and change it to something like, "Sets the current buffer in a window, then restores the cursor to its current position".

> I guess another compromise could be to add a noautocmd option to nvim_win_set_buf, too?

Unfortunately `nvim_win_set_buf` lacks an `opts` dict, and it's currently a violation of the API contract to add more parameters, at least until #33392 is merged.

Despite that, `vim._with` should be used instead (after it's public), which can apply `noautocmd` (and other modifiers) to any Lua block. (In retrospect, me adding `noautocmd` to `nvim_open_win` was a mistake :grin:)

> The "without side-effects" doc is definitely misleading.

Agreed. It definitely needs an update. :+1:

> Could consider blocking Enter/Leave events (excluding BufWin*) only for non-current windows (like nvim_open_win)

I wonder if this is worth considering? :thinking:

> Agreed. It definitely needs an update. ðŸ‘

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/37201

> > Could consider blocking Enter/Leave events (excluding BufWin*) only for non-current windows (like nvim_open_win)
> 
> I wonder if this is worth considering? ðŸ¤”

So the events would only fire events for `new_win` and `new_buf` in my example snippet?
That sounds reasonable to me, if it's consistent with other functions. But I guess no matter how we change it, it'll break some plugins...

> > > Could consider blocking Enter/Leave events (excluding BufWin*) only for non-current windows (like nvim_open_win)
> > 
> > 
> > I wonder if this is worth considering? ðŸ¤”
> 
> So the events would only fire events for `new_win` and `new_buf` in my example snippet? That sounds reasonable to me, if it's consistent with other functions. But I guess no matter how we change it, it'll break some plugins...

Hmm, there's one potential issue:
The condition for disabling Enter and Leave events in `nvim_open_win` is:

```c
// win_set_buf temporarily makes `wp` the curwin to set the buffer.
// If not entering `wp`, block Enter and Leave events. (cringe)
const bool au_no_enter_leave = curwin != wp && !fconfig.noautocmd;
```

If we move that into `win_set_buf`, `nvim_open_win` loses the `!fconfig.noautocmd` condition.
`block_autocmds()` increments a different variable (`autocmd_blocked` vs. `autocmd_no_enter` + `autocmd_no_leave`), so maybe the `!fconfig.noautocmd` check is redundant? The `window_spec` passes without it...

> Yup, I think it's redundant.

Updated this PR and changed the commit message to mark it as breaking.

:thinking: syntax highlighting will be skipped when setting the buffer for a non-current window, until it is entered. I'm not sure if that could be seen as a regression?

Thanks. Let's see what others think.

> ðŸ¤” syntax highlighting will be skipped when setting the buffer for a non-current window, until it is entered. I'm not sure if that could be seen as a regression?

Hmm, I can't test right now, but I don't _think_ that should be happening. Is there a repro?
We're only blocking `Win/Buf/Enter/Leave` autocmds now, not all of them, so syntax should be getting enabled here by `FileType` -> `Syntax` autocmds. (or just `FileType` with the tree-sitter highlights)

> Is there a repro?

No, that was just an assumption.
I forgot that syntax highlighting is triggered by different autocommands ðŸ˜…

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

title: fix(api)!: block Enter/Leave events for non-current windows in win_set_buf
